accessibilityStatement.title: Accessibility statement
accessibilityStatement.appliesTo: This accessibility statement applies to the Child Arrangements Plan.
accessibilityStatement.usableToAsManyAsPossible: This website is run as a joint service by Justice Digital, Service Transformation and Policy. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website. For example, that means you should be able to:
accessibilityStatement.changeColours: change colours, contrast levels and fonts using browser or device settings
accessibilityStatement.zoomIn: zoom in up to 400% without the text spilling off the screen
accessibilityStatement.speechRecognition: navigate most of the website using a keyboard or speech recognition software
accessibilityStatement.screenReader: listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
accessibilityStatement.simpleToUnderstand: We've also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
accessibilityStatement.abilityNet: has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.
accessibilityStatement.htmlVersion: There is also an HTML version of this statement.
accessibilityStatement.offline: can be opened in any web browser offline
accessibilityStatement.notFullyAccessible: We know some parts of this website are not fully accessible:
knownIssues: Screen reader users may struggle with some of the links.
Screen reader users will struggle with access to the exported PDF.
Screen reader users may struggle to interact with some of the buttons on the page.
accessibilityStatement.reportProblems: If you find any problems not listed on this page or think we're not meeting accessibility requirements, contact: {{ contactEmail }}
accessibilityStatement.alternativeFormats: If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read, audio recording or braille:
accessibilityStatement.responseTime: We'll consider your request and get back to you in 5 working days.
accessibilityStatement.equalityCommission: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the 'accessibility regulations'). If you're not happy with how we respond to your complaint,
accessibilityStatement.technicalInfo: Technical information about this website's accessibility
accessibilityStatement.commitment: The Ministry of Justice is committed to making its website accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.
accessibilityStatement.wcagStandard: The website has been tested against the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2 AA standard.
accessibilityStatement.partialCompliance: This website is partially compliant with the
accessibilityStatement.nonCompliances: AA standard, due to the non-compliances listed below.
accessibilityStatement.nonCompliance: The website does not comply for the following reasons:
accessibilityStatement.nonAccessibleReason: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons:
accessibilityStatement.doesNotComply: The website does not comply for the following reasons:
nonComplianceReasons: Some of the links are displayed as raw URLs with no accessible text. 2.4.4 link purpose (in context).
The exported PDFs are not accessible. 1.3.1 info and relationships.
Some buttons lack accessible text. 2.4.4 purpose (in context).
Some buttons have a conditional reveal which is not allowed for this button type. 4.1.2 name, role, value.
accessibilityStatement.fixTimeline: We plan to address these issues by early 2026.
accessibilityStatement.replacePdf: The team intends to replace the PDF with accessible content.
accessibilityStatement.statementDate: This statement was prepared on 14th October 2025. It was last reviewed on 14th October 2025.
accessibilityStatement.testingDetails: The test was carried out by a member of the MoJ digital accessibility team in March 2025. The most viewed pages were tested using automated testing tools by our website team.
accessibilityStatement.futureAudit: A further audit of the website will be scheduled to be carried out to the WCAG 2.2 AA standard by early 2026.

contactUs.title: Contact us
contactUs.reportProblem: To report a problem or suggest improvements to this service, you can email:
contactUs.onlyUseForFeedback: This email address should only be used for feedback on the digital service.
contactUs.cannotAnswerQuestions: We cannot answer any questions about child arrangement plans that have already been created.

cookies.title: Cookies
cookies.name: Name
cookies.aboutCookies:
Propose a child arrangements plan puts small files (known as ‘cookies’) onto your computer to collect information about how you browse the service.

Cookies are used to:

  • remember your progress
  • measure how you use the service so it can be updated and improved based on your needs

Propose a child arrangements plan cookies aren't used to identify you personally.

You'll normally see a message before we store a cookie on your computer.

Find out more about how to manage cookies.
cookies.howCookiesAreUsed: How cookies are used in this service
cookies.essentialCookiesUse: Essential cookies are needed for the service to work. We do not need to ask for permission to use them.
cookies.rememberingProgress:
Remembering your progress

We will store cookies to remember your application progress in this computer and to expire your session after 120 minutes of inactivity, and to remember the password you have entered to access the service.
cookies.sessionPurpose: Saves your current progress in this computer and tracks inactivity periods
cookies.authenticationPurpose: Saves the password you entered to access the service
cookies.cookiesMessage:
Cookies message

You may see a banner when you visit Propose a child arrangements plan inviting you to accept or reject optional cookies. We’ll set a cookies so that your computer knows you’ve seen it and not to show it again, and also to store your settings.
cookies.aboutOptionalCookies:
Measuring service usage (Google Analytics)

We use Google Analytics software to collect information about how you use Propose a child arrangements plan. We do this to help make sure the service is meeting the needs of its users and to help us make improvements

Google Analytics stores information about:

  • the pages you visit
  • how long you spend on each page
  • how you got to the service
  • what you click on while you’re visiting the service

We don't collect or store your personal information (for example your name or address) so this information can't be used to identify who you are.

We don't collect or store your personal information (for example your name or address) so this information can't be used to identify who you are.

Google Analytics sets the following cookies:
cookies.acceptOptionalCookies: Do you want to accept analytics cookies?
cookies._gaCookiePurpose: Checks if you’ve visited the service before. This helps us count how many people visit our site.
cookies._ga_IdCookiePurpose: Used by Google Analytics to find and track an individual session with your device.

privacyNotice.title: Privacy notice
privacyNotice.committedToSecurity: The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) is committed to the protection and security of your personal information.
privacyNotice.describeHowAndWhy: This notice describes how and why we are using such information. This privacy notice describes how we collect and use personal information during and after your relationship with us, in accordance with data protection law. This notice will be updated regularly.
privacyNotice.typesOfPersonalData:
The type of personal data we process

We currently collect and use the following information:

  • the first name of both parents or carers
  • the first names of all the children

We collect and process information related to child arrangement planning to help you create a customised child arrangement planning. However, we do not collect personally identifiable information (PII), such as names, addresses, or contact details.

Because we are not gathering information that can be used to identify you, many data protection rights do not apply. We encourage you not to include this type of detail in your plan. So long as you do not enter information we do not ask for in the service, we do not gather enough information to identify who you are.

The types of information that we collect which are not personally identifiable may include:

  • general details about child arrangements, such as preferred schedules and pick up locations
  • your contact preferences
  • user interactions with our platform, including navigation behaviour and feature usage, to improve our service
privacyNotice.howWeGetPersonalData:
How we get your personal data and why we have it

Most of the personal information we process is provided to us directly by you. The information you provide is used to generate a customised child arrangements plan that you can download and share with your co-parent. The information you provide allows us to structure the plan based on your specific needs, ensuring it accurately reflects the arrangements you propose for your children.

This data collection is essential for:

  • personalising the plan to fit your parenting situation
  • making sure that the download plan document you produce includes all the details you need to support your co-parenting arrangements
  • providing you with a version of the plan that can be downloaded for easy reference and sharing

We only collect the information necessary to generate your child arrangement plan and do not use it for any other purposes without your consent.

We do not share the information you provide with any other organisation or government department. The details you enter to create your child arrangement plan are used solely for generating your personalised plan document. Under the UK General Data Protection Regulation (UK GDPR), the lawful bases we rely on for processing this information are:

(a) Your consent. You are able to withdraw your consent at any time. The easiest way to do this is to delete your browser cookies. Guidance on how to do that is here. If you want to ask us to delete your cookie data please contact us.
privacyNotice.internationalTransfers:
International data transfers

There are no international transfers.
privacyNotice.howWeStorePersonalData:
How we store your personal data

Personal data is stored only while you create your plan and for up to 30 days afterwards.
privacyNotice.howToComplain:
How to complain

If you have any concerns about our use of your personal data, you can contact the MoJ data protection officer:

Data Protection Officer
Ministry of Justice
10th Floor, Post Point 10.31
102 Petty France
London
SW1H 9AJ

dpo@justice.gov.uk

You can also complain to the ICO if you are unhappy with how we have used your data.

Information Commissioner’s Office
Wycliffe House
Water Lane
Wilmslow
Cheshire
SK9 5AF

Helpline number: 0303 123 1113
ICO website:https://www.ico.org.uk
privacyNotice.preparedDate: This statement was prepared on 11 March 2025.

termsAndConditions.title: Terms and conditions
termsAndConditions.agree: By using this service you agree to these terms and conditions.
termsAndConditions.accurateAndComplete: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) runs this service. We try to make sure the information we provide is accurate and complete and the service is always available and virus free.
termsAndConditions.noLiabilityFor: The MoJ accepts no liability for:
termsAndConditions.unableToAccess: you being unable to access the service (for example due to high demand or because we've taken it down for maintenance)
termsAndConditions.indirectDamages: indirect damages arising from you using the service or relying on its content
termsAndConditions.externalSites: the content and availability of external websites that link to the service or which link from it
termsAndConditions.informationAboutYouHeading: Information about you and your visits
termsAndConditions.informationAboutYou: We collect information about you in accordance with our privacy policy and our cookie policy. By using this service you agree to us collecting this information and confirm that any data you provide is accurate.
termsAndConditions.limitations: Using this service does not guarantee that you will be able to resolve your child arrangements without going to court. While this tool is designed to help you create a child arrangement plan, some cases may still require legal intervention.
termsAndConditions.misuse: You must only use this service to create a parenting plan for child(ren) that you have responsibility for and access to. You must not impersonate another person, provide false or misleading information, or use this service on behalf of someone else without their consent.
termsAndConditions.mustNotUseToHarass: You must not use this service to harass, threaten, or abuse others.
termsAndConditions.restrictionsOnUse: If you have a court order in place that restricts contact with the other parent or child, such as a no contact order, non-molestation order, or any other legal restriction, you must not use this service to contact them. Doing so could be a breach of the order and may have legal consequences. If you are unsure whether a legal order affects your ability to use this service, seek legal advice before proceeding.

safetyCheck.title: Safety check
safetyCheck.workWithPartner: This service asks you to work with your parenting partner to agree a plan for your children. You need to be able to state your needs and views without feeling intimidated.
safetyCheck.safeAndConfident: Do you feel safe and confident?
safetyCheck.error: Select whether you feel safe and confident or not

notSafe.title: Finding the right route for you
notSafe.content:
This service may not be right for you if you’ve experienced domestic abuse.

Find out how to recognise domestic abuse.

Get help and advice on making child arrangements when there’s been domestic abuse.
notSafe.feelConfident: If you feel confident that you can discuss things without feeling intimidated,

childrenSafetyCheck.title: Children’s safety
childrenSafetyCheck.childrenMayBeAtRisk: Children may be at risk if there has been:
childrenSafetyCheck.domesticAbuse: any form of domestic abuse or violence, even if the abuse was not directed at the children
childrenSafetyCheck.drugsOrAlcohol: misuse of drugs, alcohol or other substances
childrenSafetyCheck.otherConcerns: any other safety or welfare concerns that place anyone at significant risk of harm
childrenSafetyCheck.error: Select whether the children are safe or not

childrenNotSafe.title: Getting help
childrenNotSafe.content:
It may not be appropriate to make child arrangements if there’s any risk of harm to the children.

Get advice on protecting children from abuse.

Citizens Advice has advice on making child arrangements when there’s been domestic abuse.
childrenNotSafe.feelConfident: If you feel confident that making child arrangements will not put children at risk,

doWhatsBest.title: What’s best for the children?
doWhatsBest.content:
Your child arrangements plan should reflect what is best for the children. You must consider their wants and needs when making these arrangements.

Remember, the aim is to make sure your children are as happy as they can be.
doWhatsBest.childrensNeedsFirst: I will put my children’s needs first
doWhatsBest.error: You must select the box to continue

courtOrderCheck.title: Do you already have a court order in place about your child arrangements?
courtOrderCheck.subText: This could include a prohibited steps, specific issue or consent order.
courtOrderCheck.error: Select whether you have a court order in place currently

existingCourtOrder.title: Do not continue
existingCourtOrder.doNotUse: Do not use this service if you have a court order in place.
existingCourtOrder.getHelpChangingCourtOrder: Get help on changing or enforcing a court order.

mostlyLive.title: Where will the children mostly live?

mostlyLive.arrangementMissingError: Describe the living arrangement you are proposing

whichSchedule.title: Which schedule best meets the children's needs?
whichSchedule.commonSchedules:
Here are some common schedules that can benefit children.

Alternating weeks
The children will spend one week in one household and the next week in the other.

2-2-3 schedule
Children spend two days in one household, two days in the other, then back to the first house for 3 days including the weekend.

4-4-3 schedule
Children spend three days in one household then four days in the other. The next week they switch.

2-2-5-5 schedule
Children spend two days in one household, then two days in the other. After that they spend five days in one household, then five days in the other.
whichSchedule.exactSplitWarning: An exact split of time between two households does not always suit children’s best interests.
whichSchedule.error: Describe which schedule will best meet the children's needs

itemsForChangeover.title: What items need to go between households?
itemsForChangeover.content: Items include clothes, sports kit, school equipment, toys and electronics, medicines and personal care items such as toothbrushes.

whatWillHappen.title: What will happen on special days?
whatWillHappen.content: Keep your children’s feelings at the centre of your plans for holidays and meaningful events. For example, New Year celebrations, Mother’s Day and Father’s Day, and birthdays.
whatWillHappen.error: Describe what you propose will happen on special days

whatOtherThingsMatter.otherContact: other types of contact, such as video calls

sharePlan.title: Child arrangements plan for {{{ names }}}
sharePlan.mustNowShare: You've created a proposed child arrangements plan. You must now share the plan with {{{ otherAdult }}} to get their agreement.
sharePlan.notLegallyBinding: Any plan you make using this service is not legally binding. The other person does not have to do what it says and either of you can suggest changes to it at any time.
sharePlan.sendToSecondary: Send this proposed child arrangements plan to {{{ otherAdult }}}. {{{ otherAdult }}} will have the chance to respond.
sharePlan.tryMediation: If {{{ otherAdult }}} does not respond, you can try mediation. The next step would be to apply for a court order.
sharePlan.ifYouCannotAgree: Find out more about what to do if you cannot agree.

whatWeAreTelling.title: What we're telling {{{ name }}} about this plan
whatWeAreTelling.proposedPlan: Proposed child arrangements plan for {{{ childrenNames }}}
whatWeAreTelling.initialIsAsking: {{{ senderName }}} is asking that you work together to come up with a plan for how to look after {{{ childrenNames }}}. Please read through the suggestions {{{ senderName }}} has made. You’re then invited to reply with any suggestions of your own.
whatWeAreTelling.doNotNeedToAccept: This plan you’ve been sent is not legally binding. It’s a suggestion from {{{ senderName }}}. You do not have to do what it says.
whatWeAreTelling.suggestChanges: use this form to suggest changes to what {{{ senderName }}} is proposing
whatWeAreTelling.startYourOwn: start your own proposed child arrangements plan using the propose a child arrangements plan service on GOV.UK, or by finding a similar service
whatWeAreTelling.makeCustom: make a written plan of your own without using any service or template
whatWeAreTelling.notLegallyBinding: Any plan you make using this form is not legally binding. The other person does not have to do what it says and either of you can suggest changes to it at any time.
whatWeAreTelling.benefitsHeading: The benefits of getting a written agreement in place
whatWeAreTelling.benefits: If you and {{{ senderName }}} can work together to make written child arrangements, you’re more likely to avoid court. You’re also more likely to get an arrangement that works for you. That’s because people who go to court often find the judge makes decisions that don’t suit parents or children.
whatWeAreTelling.compromise: One of the main reasons people end up in court is that they are not willing to compromise to reach agreement. It may help you avoid court if you can work with {{{ senderName }}} to find a compromise that’s best for your children.
whatWeAreTelling.childrensInput: Get your children’s input into the arrangements you are making so that they feel included and their needs are met.
whatWeAreTelling.childrenFirst: Remember to always put your children’s needs and feelings first.
whatWeAreTelling.splitMayNotBeBest: It may not be in the children’s best interests to split time exactly between households.
whatWeAreTelling.moreInfoHeading: More information about divorce and separation
whatWeAreTelling.moreInfo: Check GOV.UK to find what support is available. You can search for topics including:
whatWeAreTelling.separatingOrDivorcing: separating or divorcing: what you need to do
whatWeAreTelling.makingChildArrangements: making child arrangements if you divorce or separate
whatWeAreTelling.safetyCheck: To make child arrangements you need to be able to state your needs and views without feeling intimidated. The other parent or carer must not be a threat to you or to your children's safety.
whatWeAreTelling.doNotContinueIf: Do not continue with this process if there has been:
whatWeAreTelling.stopIfAnyConcern: If you have any concerns about safety, stop now. Find another way to make arrangements by visiting https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/family/making-agreements-about-your-children/making-child-arrangements.
whatWeAreTelling.gettingHelpHeading: Getting help with abuse and domestic violence
whatWeAreTelling.gettingHelp: To find out more about what is child abuse and neglect, visit https://www.nspcc.org.uk/what-is-child-abuse. If you’re unsure whether you’re a victim of domestic abuse, visit https://www.gov.uk/guidance/domestic-abuse-how-to-get-help#recognise-domestic-abuse.
whatWeAreTelling.courtOrderHeading: If there is a court order in place
whatWeAreTelling.ifCourtOrderInIsPlace: If there is a court order in place, do not continue. To change or enforce an existing order, visit https://www.gov.uk/looking-after-children-divorce/change-or-enforce-an-order.

yourProposedPlan.doNotAgreeOnBasics: If you answered ‘No’, it may be helpful to find a mediator who can help you agree your child arrangements. You can get financial help with this. To find out more, go to https://www.gov.uk/looking-after-children-divorce.

planLongTermNotice.howChangesCommunicated: {{{ senderName }}} suggested that you should both give each other {{ numberOfWeeks }} weeks' notice to change long-term arrangements.

planReview.suggestedMonthsSingular: {{{ senderName }}} suggested that you should review this arrangement in 1 month's time.
planReview.suggestedYearsSingular: {{{ senderName }}} suggested that you should review this arrangement in 1 year's time.
planReview.suggestedMonthsPlural: {{{ senderName }}} suggested that you should review this arrangement in {{ number }} months' time.
planReview.suggestedYearsPlural: {{{ senderName }}} suggested that you should review this arrangement in {{ number }} years' time.

yourProposedPlan.nowSendPlan: Now send this proposed child arrangements plan back to {{{ senderName }}}. You should try to create a written record of what you have both agreed.
yourProposedPlan.notLegallyBinding: Any plan you make using this form is not legally binding. The other person does not have to do what it says and either of you can suggest changes to it at any time.
yourProposedPlan.unableToAgree: If you are unable to reach agreement about your child arrangements, you can try mediation. The next step would be to apply for a court order.
yourProposedPlan.moreInfoAndSupport: More information and support is available at https://www.gov.uk/looking-after-children-divorce.

livingAndVisiting.mostlyLive: If you do not agree, suggest where the children will mostly live
livingAndVisiting.whichSchedule: If you do not agree, suggest a schedule
livingAndVisiting.willOvernightsHappen: If you do not agree, suggest whether the children will stay overnight with {{{ adult }}}
livingAndVisiting.whichDaysOvernight: If you do not agree, suggest when the children will stay overnight with {{{ adult }}}
livingAndVisiting.willDaytimeVisitsHappen: If you do not agree, suggest whether the children will do daytime visits
livingAndVisiting.whichDaysDaytimeVisits: If you do not agree, suggest when the children will do daytime visits

handoverAndHolidays.getBetweenHouseholds: If you do not agree, suggest how the children get between households
handoverAndHolidays.whereHandover: If you do not agree, suggest where handover takes place
handoverAndHolidays.willChangeDuringSchoolHolidays: If you do not agree, suggest whether the arrangements should change during the holidays
handoverAndHolidays.howChangeDuringSchoolHolidays: If you do not agree, suggest how the arrangements should change during the holidays
handoverAndHolidays.itemsForChangeover: If you do not agree, suggest which items need to go between households

specialDays.whatWillHappen: If you do not agree, suggest what will happen on special days

otherThings.whatOtherThingsMatter: If you do not agree, suggest what other things matter to your children

decisionMaking.planLastMinuteChanges: If you do not agree, suggest how last minute changes should be communicated
decisionMaking.planLongTermNotice: If you do not agree, suggest how much notice you should give each other
decisionMaking.planReview: If you do not agree, suggest when should you review this agreement

compromise.livingAndVisiting: You can use this space to write your agreed compromise for the living and visiting section
compromise.handoverAndHolidays: You can use this space to write your agreed compromise for the handovers and holidays section
compromise.specialDays: You can use this space to write your agreed compromise for the special days section
compromise.otherThings: You can use this space to write your agreed compromise for the other things section
compromise.decisionMaking: You can use this space to write your agreed compromise for the decision making section

confirmation.checkDownloadsFolder: Check your downloads folder to view your plan.
confirmation.appreciateFeedback: We would appreciate your feedback to help us improve the service.
confirmation.emailFeedback: You can email any feedback to {{{ contactEmail }}}.
confirmation.whatDidYouThink: What did you think of this service? (takes 5 minutes)
